awd_abstract_narration:
Ores are rocks or sediments that are the source of valuable metals and minerals. Ores must be processed to recover metals and minerals, and many metals are first concentrated in mineral form, before being chemically converted to metallic form. Extraction and concentration of minerals from ores consumes an immense amount of water. For instance, 1.27 million tons of copper were produced from US mines in 2017, and this required roughly half a billion tons of water. Although metal recycling is on the rise, it has not offset the continued increase of metal use with time. Most domestic ore deposits are found in arid regions of the country (Utah, Arizona, New Mexico and Nevada), and high water demand for mineral extraction exacerbates water supply concerns for urban centers. To address the high water demand, this project will develop engineered microspheres with surface chemistry tailored to adhere to dry mineral particles in order to reduce the water consumption of mineral extraction. 

The research will focus on exploiting the strength of adhesion between chemically modified glass microspheres relative to polystyrene controls. Glass is representative of silicate minerals, which are the most ubiquitous type of minerals found in ore bodies. The glass microspheres will be chemically modified to create superhydrophobic or superhydrophilic surfaces that adhere to small mineral particles. Mineral adherence to the model glass microspheres, as a function of particle size, will be tested and modeled via a combination of drop tests, spectroscopy, and image analysis. Adhesive surface energy will be quantified using van Oss-Good-Chaudhury and Hansen solubility parameter approaches. The adhesion results will be used to develop and validate a predictive, computational model to enable process design and optimize relevant process parameters. Successful completion of the project will enable more sustainable recovery of minerals with less water consumption and reduced environmental impact. The research will be incorporated into undergraduate design projects, and graduate courses on modeling, and will support the hands-on research training of two graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mineral flotation consumes more than 100 billion gallons of water per year in the USA. This is a sustainability problem as much flotation occurs in the relatively dry southwestern states of Arizona, Nevada, and New Mexico. We have been developing a replacement mineral processing technology to significantly reduce the use of water in mineral recovery as an alternative to the froth flotation process.

In this project, we have shown the ability to separate (without water as continuous phase) spheres of silica (polar treatment) from spheres of treated silica (nonpolar treatment) such that we recover 90% of the polar material and only 10% of the nonpolar material. These values are similar to those achieved by flotation.

To achieve these results, we first developed a way to determine how strongly the mineral particles are attached to a surface. This involved building a machine that used air pressure to accelerate a disk containing mineral particles horizontally to a stationary piece. The collision of the disk with the stationary piece was filmed with high-speed video to determine the disk velocity and the time of the impact. The largest sized mineral particle left on the surface was used with the velocity and contact time to determine the attachment strength. The values found were roughly equal to the values expected from data in the scientific literature.

Following the development of this machine, the environmental conditions that optimized recovery of polar mineral particles and minimized nonpolar particle recovery were determined. The first condition to be identified was the relative humidity. Increasing the relative humidity will increase the water condensing in rough areas on a polar surface. This also implies that the roughness needs to be controlled. Several methods were tested, and a fine, stainless-steel mesh was found to work best.

The variation in adhesion has been greatly reduced compared to a flat, glass disk. It can also be concluded that a separation of different particle types could be achieved with controlled relative humidity and rough surfaces.

In addition, we have been developing methods for performing surface treatments without using a liquid solvent. Mineral particles were treated with silane coupling agent surfactants by using a planetary centrifugal mixer to dry blend the particles along with each added surfactant. A variety of surfactant amounts were used to treat the quartz (SiO2) particles. Treated quartz particles were put onto a water surface to qualitatively test if they would sink (polar particles) or if they float on the water surface (nonpolar particles).

Similar dry blending tests with fluorite (CaF2) were also performed. The fluorite particles used were -38 μm in size (0.44 m?/g specific surface area). Several different surface coverage levels were used.

While the above mentioned adhesion work was going on, two Mechanical Engineering Senior Design Teams, working over two years, were making laboratory-scale, semi-continuous prototype separators to test mineral separation at a larger scale. The final laboratory-scale prototype included a rotating circular plate at which mineral particles could be propelled at a variety of angles and velocities by a small, pneumatic gun. The key here was determining the optimum angle and velocity so that the polar particles adhere to the surface and the nonpolar particles do not adhere. The apparatus that was designed and built had temperature and humidity control.

Finally, effort was directed at modeling and simulating the adhesion process to develop a predictive computational tool of the proposed mineral separation process. Two methods were used to derive predictive models. First, the forces present as a particle approaches a surface were determined as a function of distance from the surface and whether the surface would capture a particle was determined. Under certain angular and velocity conditions, polar particles were predicted to be captured, while nonpolar particles bounce off the surface. Second, an inverse modeling technique was developed to calibrate the Cahn-Hilliard Equation and model the collecting of particles by the surface.

With respect to outreach, a variety of activities were performed. In particular, journal articles have been published, 10 conference presentation given, and one patent application disclosed. Two students participated in research experiences for undergraduates. Two Mechanical Engineering senior design projects, were undertaken to build a prototype separator. A grant to supplement this work was obtained from the South Dakota Board of Regents, and one student obtained supplemental funding from a competition sponsored by a local technology company.
